From: "Deathifier" <storey@...>
Reply-To: gladiator@yahoogroups.com
To: "Gladiator Mailing List" <gladiator@yahoogroups.com>
Subject: [gladiator] Scenario Editor information, specs, features, etc.    - 
all in one spot.
Date: Mon, 18 Jun 2001 12:52:54 +1000

Hi,
In this post I'm trying to outline what info we have and get clarification
on a few things so that everyone knows who is doing what in the design of
the new editor and so that it doesn't just fade away like some other small
projects I've seen.

There's just a small issue, windows native programs are not directly
portable to other OS's due to the way they need to be built - we can
definitely isolate and/or mark the code that is OS specific (mainly screen
drawing code, system calls) to make it easier but people won't be able to
just pick it up, put it on Linux, and compile it :)

So we need to clarify something - do we want to make it somewhat easily
portable to another OS?
Seeing as Gladiator only runs on DOS I'd say most people are either using
DOS or windows, and you can actually class those as different OS's despite
one being built ontop of the other (in most cases).
Would everyone be happy with just a Win32 (native windows) version of the
program?
Has anyone actually done porting before, or coded with porting in mind
(cause I haven't)?

Also, if you want to be listed as either a critic (ie tester) or a
programmer then post to the group, we have to pick someone to lead this and
set it up/get it start and then have someone create a forum or mailing list
for us to work in - as Bj�rn suggested.
It would probably be best to get a website, or a least a few pages, built
for the project as well so that people have a central place to go for the
latest news, versions, etc.

Once we have the editor for V8 scenarios built we should consider adding in
the option of converting other version scenarios up, that way we will have a
complete replacement for scen.exe and editor.exe

If there is anything I've left out or people want to add then point it out
on the list and I'll amend this info.

Cya's,
Deathifier
- Who hopes he won't get in trouble for posting it when the wish list
conversation is two parts beyond the new editor :)


Outline:
Done as open source project, possibly using an online service like
SourceForge.
Done in C/C++

Programming:
Bjorn Hansen
George "Cookie" Philips
Deathifier

And Tom Ricket has offered to provide us with some code snippits if we need
them.

Critics:
Daniel Paul Hightower
Ricky Der

Contributors to feature list:
dancing corpse
Daniel Paul Hightower
George "Cookie" Philips
Anyone else I missed, some ideas contributed by multiple people.

Main features:
-Make it mouse driven, with shortcut keys to regularly used options - have
an interface similar to the current editors.

- Auto scenario number changing/renumbering (Not hard really, change
filenames, change links on teleporters, reasonably straightforward).

- Enable copying and pasting of objects and items on the grid.

- Provide various brush sizes, like 1x1, 3x3 and 5x5, for faster terrain
modification.

- Allow resizing of map size.

- Include undo and redo options (how many levels?).

- Need complete and thorough documentation, including a list of features,
how to use them, and some tutorials.

- Provide the ability to modify stats for NPC's directly.

- Combines all or most of the features from scen.exe and editor.exe



Specificatoins (Thanks to Tom Ricket, and George "Cookie" Philips):

Specs Clarification:
 > >    // 8-byte string = grid name to load
 >This apparently has something to do with the internal name of the file;
 >"SCEN0000", "SCEN0030", etc..
 >
 >It doesn't seem to be *that* important, and could probably default to the
 >filename (assuming it's 8.3)

Basically, that's so that (technically) multiple scenario files can all use
the same background grid file.  For example, scen1.fss, scen2.fss, and
scen3.fss could all use a background grid file called "forest99" if you
wanted them to.

It's not a feature we ended up making much use of, though.

 > >           // 1-byte level // 2 bytes in version 7+
 > >           // 12-bytes name
 >Named characters appear in the status window when they die.. thus, it's
 >probably best if most characters have 0x00 for their first letter of their
 >name and then gibberish for the rest (standard C string)
 >
 > >           // 10 bytes reserved
 >In every map, I think it's always "MSTRMSTRMS".. but since it's reserved
 >(ie; unused) I doubt it'll matter if that gets changed.

That's just a shrinking area .. any time we updated the scenario file, if
we had already planned space for it, then an older loaded wouldn't have
trouble reading it (since it would just skip the reserved area) .. so yes,
just ignore it .. the MSTR is just initials of our names, used as filler.
